mainmatter.p: A function f: R \to R is a polynomial with coefficients in ring R if there exists n \in \N and a_0, a_1, \ldots , a_n \in R such that f(x) = a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \cdots + a_n x^n for all x \in R. We denote the set all polynomials with coefficients in R by \mathcal {P}(R).

The set of all polynomials of degree at most m with coefficients in ring R is denoted by \mathcal {P}_m (R). In other words, \mathcal {P}_m (R) = \set { p \in \mathcal {P}(R) | \deg (p) \leq m} where \mathcal {P}(R) is the set of all polynomials with coefficients in R.

A polynomial p \in \mathcal {P}(R) is said to have degree n if there exists coefficients a_0, a_1, \ldots , a_n \in R and a_n \neq 0 such that p(x) = a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \cdots + a_n x^n for all x \in R. We denote the degree of p by \deg (p) = n. For the zero polynomial, we define its degree to be - \infty.

Define D \in \mathcal {L} ( \mathcal {P}( \mathbb {R} ), \mathcal {P}( \mathbb {R} )) (recall that \mathcal {P} means set of polynomials) by D(f) = f' We can see that D a linear map.
Additivity: D(f+g) = (f+g)' = f' + g' = D(f) + D(g)
Homogeneity: D( \alpha f) = ( \alpha f)' = \alpha f' = \alpha D(f)
